review_blob:
This beer is exactly what youd expect it to be, nothing more, nothing less. So Costco came out with their microbrews many years ago brewed by Gordon Biersch...and they were lets face it, about average if not a bit underwhelming. At $21.99 for a 48 can slab you really cant expect much more than a Coors Light clone. Theyve come pretty close, but all in all this is a light lager that should be considered so. 

Pours a brilliant light straw color, exceptionally clear with high carbonation evident in the pour. The head is average, white, dissipates fairly quickly, yet leaves a good deal of web-like lacing around the glass. Zero hop presence. Theres a slight briny-ness in the aroma and nothing more. Its a clean tasting light lager with no offensive or off tastes. Not overtly sweet or cloying like many other cheap lagers. The carbonation though strong at first dissipates quickly and the second half of the glass becomes somewhat flat. Minimal aftertaste...literally none. 

This is a fine example of what a domestic macro-light lager should be. Not my favorite style though, but well above average for what it is. Definitely a fine value if its what you are in the market for.

Yes folks I AM rating this beer a 4.8. NEARLY PERFECT. I am going to be bold and say that this beer very well could be this generations version of PLINY the ELder. It is THAT big and different. I bought this bottle on a whim, thinking that most other IPAs that feature galaxy hops tend to showcase the hop in a subtle way while blending in other American C-hops. This particular beer though brings forth the Galaxy in a very unapologetic way. Pouring a light copper, slight haze, with an average amount of head, one would never expect the BLAST of galaxy hops form the first sniff. Theres a deep dank-ness about the aroma, the tropical passion-fruit aromas hit you right in the nose-hairs! It is absolutely unapologetically tropical fruit. On a plus note, they did not f this one up by complicating the malt bill. The malt is simple, straightforward, a touch of caramel sweetness and a little bit of biscuit, but not much more. The bittering is incredibly smooth, no harsh cohumolone induced pucker faces or cat pee aromas. It is so smooth that it really just rolls off the tongue and implies a slight alkali-sensation. I wish more people could try this double IPA. This IPA should push brewing to the limits and do what Dogfish head 90 and Pliny the Elder did for the last 10 years. I have a new favorite beer, and its an outcast.

On-tap at the brewery, poured into a schooner. Pours an extra light straw color, brilliant and crystal clear, very defined viewable carbonation, a thin 1-finger thick white head. Aroma is very clean, light doughy pilsener malt and a very subtle touch of esters. Clean lager-like flavors, subtle base-malt presence. Theres enough bitterness to give it a slight bite and helps with the dryness in the finish. Carbonation is evident in the mouth, enlightening and finishes dry. Alcohol strength is noticeable for the style and sits on the upper range for a Kolsch. Very smooth, a prime example of a Kolsch.

Fresh growler fill from the brewery. This is truly a very good example of a session IPA. A light-bodied yet complex malt profile is paired with a bright quenching finish that is highlighted by a lighter hop profile.

Pours a medium-pale straw, thick head that is nearly white, sudsy lacing down the sides of an imperial pint glass. Theres a subtle nutty malt profile, slightly cracker-like, a little doughy, and a very tiny hint of spiciness. Noticeable hop characteristics include stone-fruit, citrus, and woodiness. The aroma hops seem to be a bit restrained.

Body is very light and the alcohol is kept in check. Bitterness definitely lingers on the tongue long after a sip. An excellent session IPA overall.
beer_name: Black Raven Son of Birdserker SIPA

review_blob: Growler straight from the brewery; from a new keg at that! This IPA is definitely more hop forward and less balanced. Pours blonde-golden, some chill haze, head does not last long and disappears quickly. Very nice aromatics, definite tropical fruit guava-esque, gooseberry, chardonnay-ish grape character, fresh squeezed grapefruit in the background Very pleasant hop aromas yet somewhat lacking in malt character; in this instance it is OK because the hops are so forward. This IPA is incredibly light in body and has a crisp refreshing finish. The malt body is very light and has a neutral character; an ideal background that pushes the hops forward. The amount of fruit character coming out of this is like swirling a crisp New Zealand sauvignon blanc. I really like what they did with the malt bill, leaving it simple and uncomplicated. The finish is clean and very dry, making this a nice experience IPA. Excellent showing by a brewery known for the yeasty African Amber.

Pours a hazy medium copper with some golden highlights, small head, hangs around a bit but then leaves sudsy lacing. In aroma theres the normal citrus and heavy grapefruit, along with a juicy tropical hit, and berry type fruits, ever so slightly minty. Taste is well-balanced, a good sturdy sweet malt backing with a little light caramel gives way to the smooth bitterness of this IPA. Initially I got a biscuit malt aroma, but it soon dissipated. Finishes clean, lingering bitterness. Not exciting, but very good and will do in a pinch.

CAN. Pours a burnished golden with amber mid-tones, average head, good lacing. Theres a very complex hop aroma profile that borders between slightly medicinal, herbal, dank, yet also shows some berry, citrus, a little bit of minty woodiness, and peach-like stone fruit. Theres a golden malty aroma as well, just slightly doughy. Its got a bright flavor, mid-palate malt sweetness, and smooth end-palate bittering. Finishes dry and leaves a malt-ester aftertaste more than that of the hops. Very good beer.

Pours a very pretty ruby red, clear, good head. Medium caramel malt aroma hits you first, sweet toffee like aromas, theres a citrus hop background, but not too overpowering or up front. Sweetness is kept in check, well-balanced with the bitterness which is smooth. A very enjoyable double-ale.

This is an enormous beer, and I would have given it 5 stars if it wasnt for all the floaties. The pour is absolutely disgusting...and I mean that in the nicest way possible. Its hazy, theres floaties, Im sure Ill have some severe gas ALL night long, but the head is white and thick and leaves a lot of lacing. I guess you can call it a light amber in color. Its got all the good aroma characteristics, citrus, grapefruit, lemon, pine, it smells nice and pretty for the most part. Its also got that bit of buttery pastry aroma that can only be had from Pilsner malt. Flavor is awesome. Hops and hops with a smooth bitterness backed by a sweet malt backbone...and not overly caramel like some. Id say this is three times better than Hop Lava.

I was expecting a big hoppy India Pale Lager and what I got was a well-brewed Bohemian Pilsner. The hops really dont stand out much, theres just a very slight hint of citrus and thats really disappointing considering that they market it as an IPL. Theres the familiar grapefruit citrus aroma of Amarillo hops in the head, however it becomes lost in the flavor. This beer finishes with a bit of a citrus bite yet the lager esters are still dominant. The malt gives some toast and a little caramel sweetness. Not a bad American Pilsner style of beer, but definitely needs more hops to be considered an IPL.

Heres a good example where you can clearly taste the difference between a normal dry-hopped ipa and one that has been triple dry-hopped. Pours a hazy deep golden with a raucous head. Theres a strong resinous background, with fruity and floral tropical notes. The bittering is very smooth and not catty at all. Theres more citrus and tropical citrus here than anything else. Very nice beer. Very very very good.

Finally got a chance to try this beer after reading about Alesmith for the past several years. Poured from a bottle. The pour is light copper, almost deep golden, very clear, and a thick raucous head. Theres a lot of pleasant aromas coming out of the glass, yes theres grapefruit, pine, and a very delicate floral note; ester-like, but not really. Also clearly evident is a deep dank herby hop. There is also a tangible sweetness in the aroma, but it is not caramel. Theres a lot going on here in flavor, you get a resiny hop flavor but at the same time theres a clean malt that is just slightly sweet. The finish is dry and the bitterness lingers. I am glad I tried it.

Pours a medium golden with some amber highlights. Head is light tan, some breaking and some lacing. Theres a bit of bubblegum in the aroma, some woodiness and forest-like verging on mint. Theres also aromas of grapefruit and spring flowers, very slight pine at the finishing note. Tastes slightly sweet, light caramel, a straightforward malt base. Slightly above average in relation to other Pale Ales from the Northwest.

beer_brewer_name: Portland Brewing Company (Pyramid - North American Breweries)
review_blob: Pours a hazy and slightly cloudy light straw, definitely strong carbonation and some sparse white foam that leaves decent lacing. Theres a strong pilsner-like malt aroma that arises from the glass, grassy notes, along with some DMS and corn. There is no distinctive hop presence. Theres a neutral taste overall, lager-like in character, a bit of fruitiness and plain, neutral malt. Although the carbonation is high, the finish is still lacking the thirst quenching/dry finish that should be found in Blonde and Cream ales. Overall its a plain and simple lawnmower beer.
beer_name: Fire Station 5 Golden Brigade Blonde Ale

review_blob: From the bottle. Pours a very hazy light copper color, some head which dissipates fairly quickly. Theres a distinct graininess in the aroma, a little sweet doughy-wheat like which is then followed up by the classic Cascade hop aroma. Some citrus, but mainly grapefruit and old orange peel. Flavor up-front is medium caramel with some biscuit flavors, malty munich notes come through, some are rich and caramel-like, others more savory. Theres also a bit of a pastry-like and also nutty note to the malt. Finishes clean, not completely dry, but enough for the bitterness to balance. As early as five years ago I would have probably given this beer a much higher score, however because of the onslaught of new hop-variety driven iipas, it does not fare as well. Still though, solid.

Pours an extralight copper, golden highlights, a moderate amount of whitish foam, evident carbonation. Theres a lemony sudsy aroma, slightly resinous, with a definite light floral note. Very faint amounts of very light caramel malt, theres a neutral base malt. Light bodied, good carbonation helps it finish dry, slightly medicinal bitterness at the end. Interesting use of Zythos hops although the Galena lends some catty qualities. Not bad, but not outstanding and in hindsight it does not meet expectations considering this brewerys outstanding portfolio.

This is a pretty beer. Pours with intensely thick white head, and its body is a sparkling clear deep golden with light-orange highlights. The initial aroma tells you that it is an American pale ale, but upon closer inspection it is much more than basic citrus, definitely not dank, theres a wonderful sweet tropical fruit note, lychee fruits, lemon, light pine, tangerine. Flavor is clean, touches of crystal malt dont play a major role, the hop flavor takes on a quenching step and plays along with a slightly toasty malt flavor. The tropical note runs all along through the finish which is nicely dry. This is an absolutely fantastic American pale ale and because of the characteristics of new hop varieties, this beer reflects what the new standard should be.

A previous reviewer hit it right on the head when he said that it has elegant spicy herbal tones. Pours a deep amber/ruby with a thick puff of beige head. Nose is fruity, definite yeast character as well as malt esters really shine through. Citrus hop characteristics are really restrained. Chewy caramel malt, slightly toasty, medium sweet on the tongue and well-rounded bitter finish. May come across as too sweet for some, could be seen as cloying along with the fruitiness from the yeast. Hops come across as a bit catty/catnippy that linger on the palate.

Perfume-like in aroma, pours a hazy light amber with a thick cap of off-white foam. Aromas of Valencia orange, light pine, citrus floral, lychee, juicy-fruit gum, grenadine-like, and a candy-like sweetness, with a slight toasty aspect. Taste upfront is moderately sweet, a medium caramel sweetness, a slight malty richness which is then followed with a smooth bittering. Finishes dry, lingers bitter. Very very good.

Not terrible. A below-average go-to Australian style pale lager draught in bottle form. Lager-like yeast characteristics rise out of the glass, slight sulfur, lightly toasty, and a little corny aroma. Tastes like your average macro-brew lager, unoffensive yet underwhelming. Slight tinny/metallic flavor in the finish. Thin in flavor overall but it at least does not display a sugary or fake sweetness. Middle of the road at best.

Pours a medium amber, slight reddish overtones, minimal head that leaves a decent lacing. Faint aromas of light pine, citrus, grapefruit pith, and slightly sweet caramel. The malt is clean, some light caramel sweetness, but primarily balanced with a firm bitterness. Yeast esters are kept in check and this beer is fairly clean. The hops unfortunately do not push well through the flavor, but do provide a smooth and clean bitterness. Probably one of the better examples of the APA style from Australia.

Interesting to try, this is considered a fruit beer even though the shiraz grapes really are just an accessory in this brew. Pours a clear light amber, minimal head, some reddish highlights. The shiraz comes out in the aroma as very slight, theres mainly a medium caramel malt aroma and a slightly dank fruitiness. Tastes slightly acidic, a sharp medium caramel twang, with a small bit of generic citrus hop aroma. Not as impressive as it could be and definitely underwhelming.
beer_name: Saltram of Barossa Pepperjack Hand Crafted Ale

review_blob: Pours a medium golden, very clear with some loose off-white head. Nose is unimpressive at best, some citrus, hint of grapefruit and a light non-distinct caramel presence. Taste is clean, not a lot of malt character, some hops but not really enough. Hop flavor profile is one-sided and a bit flat. It would be nice to see a LOT more finishing hops in this beer. Malt profile would work better with a higher starting gravity however in this beer it falls flat and a bit thin.
beer_name: Matilda Bay Fat Yak Pale Ale

review_blob: I really wanted to like this beer based on the deScription, however it falls short of the given expectations. Pours a pale yellow, somewhat hazy rather than cloudy, thin white head. Aroma is weak, Light notes of grapefruit, lemon, some dry white grape, slightly doughy. Its a simple and straightforward flavor profile. No noticeable caramel or sweet flavors. Clean malt, but could use much more character. Finish is a little astringent, slightly sour and it leaves a undesirable flavor. The bitterness is firmer than most Australian versions of the pale ale, yet it has a long way to come.

Poured straight from a can, a medium-golden yellowish hue, very little head, very clear. Although they call it a bitter, its truly a pale australian lager in style. Theres a definite fruity yeasty aroma that comes forth, a little grassy, some light cracker. Flavor is pretty straightforward, slightly malty, a little light biscuit, no distinguishing hop flavors or aroma. Somewhat of a watery finish, a fair bit of bitterness rounds out whatever sweetness there is. An average pale lager at best, and definitely better than a few other mass produced lagers from Oz.

Australias jump into the highly hopped pale ales seems to fall a bit short of what it could be in this example. Pours a medium golden with a bit of amber highlights, limited foam. Aromas of light citrus, grapefruit, upfront along with a few non-distinct tropical notes. Displays a modest and neutral malt character. As an american pale ale, this beer could use a lot more hop character, especially in the finish which tails off slightly watery. An average at best american pale ale, however it is a step in the right direction for pale ales in Australia.

Pours a medium golden, very hazy, with absolutely zero head. A bottled version of the rare "light (in color) mild" style. Theres a very faint and weak aroma of sour grains, a very slight doughy smell, and a somewhat medicinal smell. Super weak flavor, watery yet astringently bitter at the same time. Theres also a strong aftertaste of dried grass and it comes across as dusty with a catty, muddled flavor. The carbonation for the style is much too high and adds to the astringent finish. Not a good example of the style.

Pours from the bottle a medium golden with a slight amber shadow, minimal white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is neutral, slightly dusty, and a little grainy, no noticeable hop notes. Tastes very plain, no distinct malt flavors or esters. Hop presence is equally nil. There really is nothing distinguishing about this beer other than a slight metallic taste in the finish. There has got to be a better alternative In Australia where a bottle of beer will run you $4+ at the grocery store.

As much as I love the commercials and advertisements, this is a terrible terrible beer. I actually just flew in to Australia from the US and this was the first beer on my list. Sweet and artificially sugary, no hop character at all, some really strong fruity esters, medicinal in sweetness, carbonation is OK if a little low. I waited years and years to try this beer and now I am more than happy to wait years and years to have it again.

The deScription says "hop-jacked lager" which makes me envision some sort of imperial pale lager with tons of hops. Nope, not even close. Pours out a light copper with golden highlights, a small amount of thickened white head that leaves a nice bit of lacing. Initial aroma is of sweet doughy pilsner malt, dry cereal, very light floral, and some heavy lager esters. Theres a sweet doughy malt flavor, slightly toasty and a touch of a corn-like sweetness at the end. The bitterness is a little higher than in other Shiner beers which means it is almost nearing balanced, but still not quite. The finish leaves a few of the rich malt-notes that one would be looking for in a Bavarian style lager. The bitterness however much they advertise, should be much firmer and stronger. There are no distinct hop characteristics that would set this beer apart from others in their lineup, however the additional bitterness makes this better than the original Bock.

The initial pour makes it look really pretty and that maybe just maybe Shiner has made a beer that might actually surprise you...in a good way. Unfortunately though this one disappoints, just like all the other beers in Shiners lineup. It pours a pretty and clear deep burnished golden with ruby highlights, some whitish head that hangs around for a bit. A glass swirl brings about a slightly grassy-herbal aroma, a very subtle candy-like malt sweetness, a touch of esters that seem Belgian-yeast-like, and an earthy hop profile somewhere around a blackberry mixed with a dank herbaciousness, and ending with a distinct floral note. The flavor however will completely underwhelm you, dry, and sour! Almost as if there was a bit of brett. No body whatsoever and no residual sweetness. The carbonation dries it up even more so and it leaves you with an unsatisfying lactic taste on the back of your tongue. No bueno.

Poured from a "Shiner Premium Beer" bottle which supposedly is the same as the Blonde but marketed slightly differently. Strong carbonation is noticed immediately, medium cap of white head, very clear and extra light straw in color. Strong aroma of lager-like esters, definite sulfur, with notes of dried hay. Its a clean and nearly flavorless lager hinting at flaked corn. No distinct malt flavors or esters, no noticeable hop varieties. Even with gobs of carbonation this beer finishes with a watery palate and leaves a slightly medicinal aftertaste.

I have tried this beer on numerous occasions, whether on draft or from a bottle. Every time it never fails to underwhelm me. Usually some hot girl I know will just gush about this beer and Ill be like ok, Im willing to try it AGAIN because she says so. Pours purpley-amber with almost no head, and whatever head that forms, quickly dissipates. Aroma is muddy, candy-sweet with a slight piney aroma, a bit more spruce-like really. Sugary sweet up front in flavor, with a mixed candy-like sweetness. There really isnt enough bitterness to hold up the sugar, it seems bitter in the "old orange peel pith" kinda way. Similar to frozen concentrated orange juice. Ive tried to like this beer on many many occasions, yet it still fails to impress me.

Definitely an above average IPA. Pours a beautiful red with a moderate amount of white foam, decent clarity. A very fresh lemony and tropical fruit aroma hits you immediately in the face, and is then followed by a dark prune-like sweetness. Smooth bittering that is just slightly more than needed. Well-balanced hop bitterness and malt sweetness. Medium bodied and finishes clean. Very very good.

Pours a coppery orange, bordering on amber with a nice thick and dense off-white head. Immediate malt based aromas of munich and medium caramel malts are followed by a very familiar grapefruit and orange citrus aroma, slightly floral background. Tastes caramel-sweet and toasty, with a slight nod to irish red ale yet also a bit of malt esters like a lot of German ales. The hops are simple and straightforward and supply a balanced bitterness. Body comes across on the heavier side for an IPA. A filling beer and the alcohol sneaks up on you. The cause is also a good thing.

Pours a very clear light amber with golden highlights, a good bit of light tan foam that relinquishes to a web-like lacing on the glass. Aroma up front is definite citrus, grapefruit specifically, a very bright citrus aroma as compared to other "dank" aromas. clean with some background pine and very slightly floral, overall a very good hop combination that comes across as pleasant. The color makes you think that there would be a significant amount of caramel flavor, however the caramel is quite restrained, just sweet enough to balance out the smooth bitterness. Its also nice to see an IPA on the lower end of the ABV range. Very good overall.

Pours a very light golden, somewhat clear with a light haze and average white head. Aroma up front is Pilsner malt, a little rich with melanoidins and a cracker-like aroma. Theres a subtle and very faint aroma of dried candied orange peel in the background, lightly spicy, and slightly floral. Flavor is immediately of pilsner malt, toasty and malty rich. The hops dont really come through in the flavor, it could be Challenger hops or it could very well be any noble hop. Finish is dry and clean. For being advertised as a dry-hopped beer this does not impress. I was expecting more hop aroma and flavor. Still though its a decent drink.
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2014

Pours a moderately cloudy deep golden with definite amber highlights, thick and fluffy off-white head that stands for a long time like shaving cream. Theres a very straightforward hop aroma, grapefruit and lightly floral. Malt aroma is clean with a distinct addition of munich adding richness and toastiness to the nose. Theres a toasty note to the malt flavor and it comes across more robust than sweet. Hop bitterness is smooth and lingering, leaving a desirable aftertaste. Light fruity esters are evident, but not overpowering and definitely compliment the hops. This is a very good example of a Northwest American IPA.

Pours a medium burnished amber with golden highlights, a tad bit of haze and a vigilant cream colored head. Aroma is primarily orange citrus, old oranges, grapefruit pith, yet earthy and somewhat herbal and dank, some very subdued piney notes lends itself to the background. Flavors of neutral malt with some medium-light caramel sweetness, good carbonation. Firm bitterness lingers and takes on a bit of a harsh aftertaste reminiscent of grapefruit pith. An above average IPA, but nothing distinctly outstanding.

This is an incredibly bad mass-produced maco-lager beer. I find it hard to believe that it is brewed with 100% barley malt because of its cider-like sugariness. Pours a lovely extra-light color however and it also has a very crisp and light finish. Not as watery as most mass-produced Asian beers, but it still lacks in body.

Pours a lovely dark golden, orangey-amber highlights, semi-hazy, thick cap of whitish foam. Citrusy hops are balanced by a slight fruity aroma, distinctly grapefruit, hop-coney forest, soil. Tastes very well balanced, a decent malt backbone that finishes dry and has a medium-light body. No overbearing caramel notes nor cloying sweetness. Lingering bitterness is delightful. Amarillo hops really play second fiddle to Centennial and Cascade in this beer. A very good example of the current standard for IPAs.

Pours a beautifully clear light amber with golden highlights, a thick cap of light tan foam that is densely formed. Some sulfur in the nose along with toast, slightly sweet, and slightly bready. No distinguishable hop presence. Tastes like a decent marzen beer, theres a bit of fruity esters from the yeast and some malt esters as well. Nutty, toasty. Dark fruit comes in at the end of the taste. Not as richly malty as most import Oktoberfests and it really treads closer to Vienna Lager in terms of malt-body. Bitterness is unspecific but smooth. Overall a drinkable Marzen beer that lacks the extra oomph that would separate it from the pack.

Pours a light golden, hazy, thin white head. Theres a tropical and light-citrus aroma, guava and passionfruit, a little biscuit and somewhat cracker-like. The wheat really impairs a biscuit-like flavor and creamy texture. Theres modest hop flavor and the bitterness is pleasant and smooth. Finish is pleasant with a smooth texture. Not a particularly big IPA, however it is unique in that the hop profile is somewhat subdued yet balanced and enhanced by the addition of wheat.

Pours a medium copper, with golden highlights, definite haze and with some substantially rocky white head. Theres a lightly floral hop aroma that gives way to moderate grapefruit, slightly dank, medium caramel, and low amounts of citrus. Malt flavor is clean, and somewhat neutral, theres a hint of candy-like sweetness that is balanced by a light body and decent bittering. The bittering is clean and does not leave any catty notes. The hops however are somewhat one-dimensional and simply straightforward. Good carbonation makes this beer finish dry and crisp. No lingering sweetness. A better than average pale ale, however it really doesnt separate itself from the rest of the pack.

Pours a deep black with some light off-whitish colored froth. Distinct aromas of pumpkin spice, most notably cinnamon and nutmeg come through the nose followed by dark roast, and some light caramel. No detectable hop presence in the aroma. Tastes like a light bodied porter that has been laced with old cinnamon and nutmeg. The spices are especially evident in the finish, as it is dry hinting at peppery, and leaves a slight slickness on the tongue perhaps from a bit of diacetyl.
beer_name: Redhook Brewery Backyard Series Pumpkin Porter

review_blob: Pours a light golden-copper, incredibly clear (as with most macros), and with average foam. Aroma is clearly Cascade hops that are somewhat restrained, the malt does not come forward in the nose. Flavor suggests at a touch of light caramel malt, but mainly clean american 2-row. There is very little hop flavor, however a smooth bittering that again is restrained. Light in body, flavor, bitterness, and finish. This overall is a very pleasant, drinkable, and unoffensive american pale ale, it however lacks in any outstanding qualities that would separate it from others. The 4.7% abv lies on the lighter side for most APAs and helps contribute to its sessionability, yet the hop flavor is one-dimensional and becomes quite boring.

Pours a very dark brown, with some ruby-like highlights, very clear with some white foam. Distinct coffee-like aromas, roasted barley, burnt toast, and some light caramel, no distinct hop presence. Medium bitterness and light sweetness help with a medium-light body. Taste is primarily coffee up front that is then followed by a light caramel and a slightly tart dryness. Toasted nutshells are also prominent in the flavor. A decent brown porter that leans more toward malt esters rather than heavy on roast and body.

Pours a deep golden with amber tones, very clear and with a lacing of thin white foam. Aromas of medium toffee, light caramel, chewy malt, and a slight bit of fruitiness. Medium mouthfeel gives way to a moderate amount of caramel sweetness, savory toffee, bit of raisin, along with a bit of diacetyl. A very light fruity and woodsy hop presence. Esters hint at either maris otter malt or Scottish ale yeast. Balance is good however there is a bit of astringency in the finish that detracts from the overall experience.

Pours a very cloudy and hazy light golden, decent white head and apparent carbonation. DMS, cooked corn, and esthery fruit presence in the nose, some light notes of sweet pils malt and a little bit of spice. Definite fruity flavor up front, slightly sour, and a little grassy. Finish leaves a lingering yeasty flavor, and body is medium-full. A below-average vienna lager beer that has some definite flaws. Cloudy appearance is disheartening.
